title: Angelina Jolie 'lost herself' at end of relationship with Brad Pitt
text:
Brad and Angelina split in 2016 (Picture: Getty Images for AFI)

Angelina Jolie has spoken honestly about the end of her relationship with Brad Pitt, confessing she felt like she had ‘lost herself’.

The actress reflected on her life as she opened up about leading by example to her children.

When asked if she believes in fate, she explained: ‘I don’t what my fate holds but what I am convinced of is that I am in a period of transition, like a return to my roots, a return to myself. Because, I had lost myself a bit.’

Clarifying, she added: ‘I think it happened as my relationship with Brad was coming to an end, then at the beginning of our separation. It was a complicated moment, where I didn’t recognise myself anymore, where I had become… how can I say… smaller, almost insignificant, even if it wasn’t necessarily visible.

‘I felt a deep and genuine sadness, I was hurt. On the other hand, it was interesting to reconnect with this humility and even this insignificance I was feeling. Maybe this is what being human is in the end… On top of all this, I suffered some health issues. All these things settle in you and remind you of how lucky you are of being alive.’

Speaking to French magazine Madame, the mum-of-six went on to say that rediscovering joy is a lesson she wants to teach her children.

Angelina opened up about being a mum (Picture: Getty Images for Netflix)

Brad and Angelina got married in 2014 and quickly became one of Hollywood’s most beloved couples, before splitting in 2016, 11 years after they first started dating.

The Ad Astra star also previously spoke out about how he dealt with his pain from the split.

Brad said he used ‘drugs, booze and Netflix’ to escape the pain of the split (Picture: NBCUniversal via Getty Images)

‘What I realised is that I was running to avoid tough feelings, painful feelings,’ he told CNN about their relationship ending.

‘I just didn’t know how to deal with them. Anything I found that I used for escape.

‘Those kinds of difficult feelings, I don’t know how better to describe it. It can be anything, drugs, booze, Netflix, snacks. Anything.’

However, he insisted he no longer wants to be ‘running from anything’.
